workflow.name: Telegram chat access control with user permission database
workflow.description:
# üîê n8n Workflow: Access Control for Internal Chats or Chatbots

This n8n workflow helps you restrict access to your internal chats or chatbots so that only authorized team members can interact with them. It's perfect for setups using Telegram, Slack, or other corporate messengers, where you need to prevent unauthorized users from triggering internal automations.

---

## üìå Section 1: Trigger & Input

### ‚ö° Receive Message (Telegram Trigger)

**Purpose:** Captures every incoming message from a user interacting with your Telegram bot (or another messenger).

**How it works:** When a user sends a message, it instantly triggers the workflow and passes their username or ID as input data.

**Benefit:** Acts as the entry point for verifying whether a user is allowed to proceed.

---

## üìå Section 2: Access Table Lookup

### üìã User Access Table (Data Node / Spreadsheet / DB Query)

**Purpose:** Stores all your team members and their current access status.

**Structure Example:**

| Username | Access Status |
|----------|---------------|
| user1    | granted       |
| user2    | denied        |
| user3    | granted       |

**Benefit:** Centralized access control ‚Äî you can easily update user permissions without editing the workflow.

---

## üìå Section 3: Permission Check

### üß© Check Access (IF Node)

**Purpose:** Compares the incoming user's name or ID against the access table.

**Logic:**

```
If status = granted ‚Üí Allow message to continue  
If status = denied ‚Üí Stop workflow execution
```

**Benefit:** Ensures only approved users can interact with your automations or receive responses.

---

## üìå Section 4: Response Handling

### üí¨ Send Reply (Telegram Node)

**Purpose:** Sends a message back to the user depending on their access level.

**Paths:**

* ‚úÖ **Granted:** Sends the normal bot response or triggers the main process.
* ‚ùå **Denied:** Sends no reply (or an optional "Access denied" message).

**Benefit:** Prevents unauthorized access while maintaining a seamless experience for approved users.

---

## üìä Workflow Overview Table

| Section | Node Name | Purpose |
|---------|-----------|---------|
| 1. Trigger | Receive Message | Captures incoming messages |
| 2. Access Table | User Access Table | Stores usernames + permissions |
| 3. Check | Check Access | Verifies if user has permission |
| 4. Response | Send Reply | Sends or blocks response based on status |

---

## üéØ Key Benefits

* üîê **Secure access control:** Only trusted users can trigger your internal automations.
* ‚öôÔ∏è **Dynamic management:** Easily update user permissions from a table or database.
* üß† **Lightweight setup:** Just three nodes create a fully functional access gate.
* üöÄ **Scalable foundation:** Extend it with role-based access or activity logging later.

parameters.content:
## Input data
Thread to connect Credential to connect with

## Table with a list of employees 
Select the created Data table (you can choose either Google Sheets or Airtable)

## Employee access filter
names - access statuses

## Description

üìù Access Control Flow ‚Äî Quick Guide

Telegram Trigger ‚Äî receives a message from the user.

User Access Table ‚Äî stores the list of users and their access status (granted / denied).

Check Access (IF Node) ‚Äî verifies if the user is allowed to continue.
‚ÄÉ- ‚úÖ Granted ‚Üí workflow continues.
‚ÄÉ- ‚ùå Denied ‚Üí stops or skips the response.

(Optional) ‚Äî update the user‚Äôs status in the table anytime to instantly revoke access.

üí° Use case:
Perfect for restricting access to internal bots or automations only to your team members.

## Instruction

## 1. Connect Telegram Bot
This workflow starts with a Telegram Trigger node.
In Telegram, open @BotFather

Create a bot:
/newbot
Follow prompts ‚Üí copy the Bot Token.

## 2. In n8n:
Go to Credentials ‚Üí New ‚Üí Telegram API.
Name it (e.g., ‚ÄúTelegram Access Control‚Äù).
Paste your Bot Token.

Open the Telegram Trigger node:
Select your Telegram API credential.
Make sure Updates: message is selected.
Click ‚ÄúTest Webhook‚Äù and send a test message to your bot in Telegram.
n8n should display your test message in the Test Webhook window.
‚úÖ Now your Telegram bot is connected.

## 3. Prepare the Access Table

You can use one of several data sources:
n8n Data Table (recommended for simplicity)
Google Sheets
Airtable
Notion
Add records, for example:
UserName	Access
johndoe	Granted
janedoe	Denied

Open the DataBase with employees node:
Choose your new table under ‚ÄúData Table ID‚Äù.
The workflow will automatically find a record where:
UserName == $json.message.from.username
Configure the Access Logic

## 4. In the Permission (Switch) node:

If $json.Access = Granted ‚Üí continues to the next step (No Operation node).
If $json.Access = Denied ‚Üí sends a Telegram reply ‚ÄúAccess denied‚Äù.
You can customize:
Text of the denial message in Answer Denied node (text field).
What happens on ‚ÄúGranted‚Äù output (e.g., connect your main workflow logic).

## 5. Test the Flow

Activate the workflow (set Active: ON).
Send a Telegram message to your bot.
The flow will:
Check your Telegram username.
Look it up in the data table.
Respond ‚ÄúAccess denied‚Äù or continue (depending on Access value).

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

data.details: The Filter node can be used to filter items based on a condition. If the condition is met, the item will be passed on to the next node. If the condition is not met, the item will be omitted. Conditions can be combined together by AND(meet all conditions), or OR(meet at least one condition).
